column2: _Love's Fierce Sweetness_

column2: After we had all returned to Greenwich the princess and Brandon were together frequently.
column3: After we had all returned to Greenwich the princess and Brandon were together frequently.

column2: Upon several occasions he was invited, with others, to her parlor for card playing.
column3: Upon several occasions he was invited, with others, to her parlor for card playing.

column2: But we spent two evenings, with only four of us present, prior to the disastrous events which changed everything, and of which I am soon to tell you.
column3: But we spent two evenings, with only four of us present, prior to the disastrous events which changed everything, and of which I am soon to tell you.

column2: During these two evenings the "Sailor Lass" was in constant demand.
column3: During these two evenings the "Sailor Lass" was in constant demand.

column2: This pair, who should have remained apart, met constantly in and about the palace, and every glance added fuel to the flame.
column3: This pair, who should have remained apart, met constantly in and about the palace, and every glance added fuel to the flame.

column2: Part of the time it was the princess with her troublesome dignity, and part of the time it was Mary--simply girl.
column3: Part of the time it was the princess with her troublesome dignity, and part of the time it was Mary-simply girl.

column2: Notwithstanding these haughty moods, anyone with half an eye could see that the princess was gradually succumbing to the budding woman; that Brandon's stronger nature had dominated her with that half fear which every woman feels who loves a strong man--stronger than herself.
column3: Notwithstanding these haughty moods, anyone with half an eye could see that the princess was gradually succumbing to the budding woman; that Brandon's stronger nature had dominated her with that half fear which every woman feels who loves a strong man-stronger than herself.

column2: One day the rumor spread through the court that the old French king, Louis XII, whose wife, Anne of Brittany, had just died, had asked Mary's hand in marriage.
column3: One day the rumor spread through the court that the old French king, Louis the twelfth, whose wife, Anne of Brittany, had just died, had asked Mary's hand in marriage.

column2: It was this, probably, which opened Brandon's eyes to the fact that he had been playing with the very worst sort of fire; and first made him see that in spite of himself, and almost without his knowledge, the girl had grown wonderfully sweet and dear to him.
column3: It was this, probably, which opened Brandon's eyes to the fact that he had been playing with the very worst sort of fire; and first made him see that in spite of himself, and almost without his knowledge, the girl had grown wonderfully sweet and dear to him.

column2: He now saw his danger, and struggled to keep himself beyond the spell of her perilous glances and siren song.
column3: He now saw his danger, and struggled to keep himself beyond the spell of her perilous glances and siren song.

column2: This modern Ulysses made a masterful effort, but alas! had no ships to carry him away, and no wax with which to fill his ears.
column3: This modern Ulysses made a masterful effort, but alas! had no ships to carry him away, and no wax with which to fill his ears.

column2: Wax is a good thing, and no one should enter the Siren country without it.
column3: Wax is a good thing, and no one should enter the Siren country without it.

column2: Ships, too, are good, with masts to tie one's self to, and sails and rudder, and a gust of wind to waft one quickly past the island.
column3: Ships, too, are good, with masts to tie one's self to, and sails and rudder, and a gust of wind to waft one quickly past the island.

column2: In fact, one cannot take too many precautions when in those enchanted waters.
column3: In fact, one cannot take too many precautions when in those enchanted waters.

column2: Matters began to look dark to me.
column3: Matters began to look dark to me.

column2: Love had dawned in Mary's breast, that was sure, and for the first time, with all its fierce sweetness. Not that it had reached its noon, or anything like it.
column3: Love had dawned in Mary's breast, that was sure, and for the first time, with all its fierce sweetness. Not that it had reached its noon, or anything like it.

column2: In truth, it might, I hoped, die in the dawning, for my lady was as capricious as a May day; but it was love--love as plain as the sun at rising.
column3: In truth, it might, I hoped, die in the dawning, for my lady was as capricious as a May day; but it was love-love as plain as the sun at rising.

column2: She sought Brandon upon all occasions, and made opportunities to meet him; not openly--at any rate, not with Brandon's knowledge, nor with any connivance on his part, but apparently caring little what he or any one else might see.
column3: She sought Brandon upon all occasions, and made opportunities to meet him; not openly-at any rate, not with Brandon's knowledge, nor with any connivance on his part, but apparently caring little what he or any one else might see.

column2: Love lying in her heart had made her a little more shy than formerly in seeking him, but her straightforward way of taking whatever she wanted made her transparent little attempts at concealment very pathetic.
column3: Love lying in her heart had made her a little more shy than formerly in seeking him, but her straightforward way of taking whatever she wanted made her transparent little attempts at concealment very pathetic.

column2: As for Brandon, the shaft had entered his heart, too, poor fellow, as surely as love had dawned in Mary's, but there was this difference: With our princess--at least I so thought at the time--the sun of love might dawn and lift itself to mid-heaven and glow with the fervent ardor of high noon--for her blood was warm with the spark of her grandfather's fire--and then sink into the west and make room for another sun to-morrow.
column3: As for Brandon, the shaft had entered his heart, too, poor fellow, as surely as love had dawned in Mary's, but there was this difference: With our princess-at least I so thought at the time-the sun of love might dawn and lift itself to mid heaven and glow with the fervent ardor of high noon-for her blood was warm with the spark of her grandfather's fire-and then sink into the west and make room for another sun to morrow.

column2: But with Brandon's stronger nature the sun would go till noon and there would burn for life.
column3: But with Brandon's stronger nature the sun would go till noon and there would burn for life.

column2: The sun, however, had not reached its noon with Brandon, either; since he had set his brain against his heart, and had done what he could to stay the all-consuming orb at its dawning.
column3: The sun, however, had not reached its noon with Brandon, either; since he had set his brain against his heart, and had done what he could to stay the all consuming orb at its dawning.

column2: He knew the hopeless misery such a passion would bring him, and helped the good Lord, in so far as he could, to answer his prayer, and lead him not into temptation.
column3: He knew the hopeless misery such a passion would bring him, and helped the good Lord, in so far as he could, to answer his prayer, and lead him not into temptation.

column2: As soon as he saw the truth, he avoided Mary as much as possible.
column3: As soon as he saw the truth, he avoided Mary as much as possible.

column2: As I said, we had spent several evenings with Mary after we came home from Windsor, at all of which her preference was shown in every movement.
column3: As I said, we had spent several evenings with Mary after we came home from Windsor, at all of which her preference was shown in every movement.

column2: Some women are so expressive under strong emotion that every gesture, a turn of the head, a glance of the eyes, the lifting of a hand or the poise of the body, speaks with a tongue of eloquence, and such was Mary.
column3: Some women are so expressive under strong emotion that every gesture, a turn of the head, a glance of the eyes, the lifting of a hand or the poise of the body, speaks with a tongue of eloquence, and such was Mary.

column2: Her eyes would glow with a soft fire when they rested upon him, and her whole person told all too plainly what, in truth, it seemed she did not care to hide.
column3: Her eyes would glow with a soft fire when they rested upon him, and her whole person told all too plainly what, in truth, it seemed she did not care to hide.

column2: When others were present she would restrain herself somewhat, but with only Jane and myself, she could hardly maintain a seemly reserve.
column3: When others were present she would restrain herself somewhat, but with only Jane and myself, she could hardly maintain a seemly reserve.

column2: During all this time Brandon remained cool and really seemed unconscious of his wonderful attraction for her.
column3: During all this time Brandon remained cool and really seemed unconscious of his wonderful attraction for her.

column2: It is hard to understand why he did not see it, but I really believe he did not.
column3: It is hard to understand why he did not see it, but I really believe he did not.

column2: Although he was quite at ease in her presence, too much so, Mary sometimes thought, and strangely enough sometimes told him in a fit of short-lived, quickly repented anger that always set him laughing, yet there was never a word or gesture that could hint of undue familiarity.
column3: Although he was quite at ease in her presence, too much so, Mary sometimes thought, and strangely enough sometimes told him in a fit of short-lived, quickly repented anger that always set him laughing, yet there was never a word or gesture that could hint of undue familiarity.

column2: It would probably have met a rebuff from the princess part of her; for what a perversity, both royal and feminine, she wanted all the freedom for herself.
column3: It would probably have met a rebuff from the princess part of her; for what a perversity, both royal and feminine, she wanted all the freedom for herself.

column2: In short, like any other woman, she would rather love than be loved, that is, until surrender day should come; then of course....
column3: In short, like any other woman, she would rather love than be loved, that is, until surrender day should come; then of course....

column2: After these last two meetings, although the invitations came frequently, none was accepted.
column3: After these last two meetings, although the invitations came frequently, none was accepted.

column2: Brandon had contrived to have his duties, ostensibly at least, occupy his evenings, and did honestly what his judgment told him was the one thing to do; that is, remain away from a fire that could give no genial warmth, but was sure to burn him to the quick.
column3: Brandon had contrived to have his duties, ostensibly at least, occupy his evenings, and did honestly what his judgment told him was the one thing to do; that is, remain away from a fire that could give no genial warmth, but was sure to burn him to the quick.

column2: I saw this only too plainly, but never a word of it was spoken between us.
column3: I saw this only too plainly, but never a word of it was spoken between us.

column2: The more I saw of this man, the more I respected him, and this curbing of his affections added to my already high esteem.
column3: The more I saw of this man, the more I respected him, and this curbing of his affections added to my already high esteem.

column2: The effort was doubly wise in Brandon's case.
column3: The effort was doubly wise in Brandon's case.

column2: Should love with his intense nature reach its height, his recklessness would in turn assert itself, and these two would inevitably try to span the impassable gulf between them, when Brandon, at least, would go down in the attempt.
column3: Should love with his intense nature reach its height, his recklessness would in turn assert itself, and these two would inevitably try to span the impassable gulf between them, when Brandon, at least, would go down in the attempt.

column2: His trouble, however, did not make a mope of him, and he retained a great deal of his brightness and sparkle undimmed by what must have been an ache in his heart.
column3: His trouble, however, did not make a mope of him, and he retained a great deal of his brightness and sparkle undimmed by what must have been an ache in his heart.

column2: Though he tried, without making it too marked, to see as little of Mary as possible, their meeting once in a while could not be avoided, especially when one of them was always seeking to bring it about.
column3: Though he tried, without making it too marked, to see as little of Mary as possible, their meeting once in a while could not be avoided, especially when one of them was always seeking to bring it about.

column2: After a time, Mary began to suspect his attempts to avoid her, and she grew cold and distant through pique.
column3: After a time, Mary began to suspect his attempts to avoid her, and she grew cold and distant through pique.

column2: Her manner, however, had no effect upon Brandon, who did not, or at least appeared not to notice it.
column3: Her manner, however, had no effect upon Brandon, who did not, or at least appeared not to notice it.

column2: This the girl could not endure, and lacking strength to resist her heart, soon returned to the attack.
column3: This the girl could not endure, and lacking strength to resist her heart, soon returned to the attack.

column2: Mary had not seen Brandon for nearly two weeks, and was growing anxious, when one day she and Jane met him in a forest walk near the river.
column3: Mary had not seen Brandon for nearly two weeks, and was growing anxious, when one day she and Jane met him in a forest walk near the river.

column2: Brandon was sauntering along reading when they overtook him. Jane told me afterwards that Mary's conduct upon coming up to him was pretty and curious beyond the naming.
column3: Brandon was sauntering along reading when they overtook him. Jane told me afterwards that Mary's conduct upon coming up to him was pretty and curious beyond the naming.

column2: At first she was inclined to be distant, and say cutting things, but when Brandon began to grow restive under them and showed signs of turning back, she changed front in the twinkling of an eye and was all sweetness.
column3: At first she was inclined to be distant, and say cutting things, but when Brandon began to grow restive under them and showed signs of turning back, she changed front in the twinkling of an eye and was all sweetness.

column2: She laughed and smiled and dimpled, as only she could, and was full of bright glances and gracious words.
column3: She laughed and smiled and dimpled, as only she could, and was full of bright glances and gracious words.

column2: She tried a hundred little schemes to get him to herself for a moment--the hunting of a wild flower or a four-leaved clover, or the exploration of some little nook in the forest toward which she would lead him--but Jane did not at first take the hint and kept close at her heels.
column3: She tried a hundred little schemes to get him to herself for a moment-the hunting of a wild flower or a four leaved clover, or the exploration of some little nook in the forest toward which she would lead him-but Jane did not at first take the hint and kept close at her heels.

column2: Mary's impulsive nature was not much given to hinting--she usually nodded and most emphatically at that--so after a few failures to rid herself of her waiting lady she said impatiently: "Jane, in the name of heaven don't keep so close to us.
column3: Mary's impulsive nature was not much given to hinting-she usually nodded and most emphatically at that-so after a few failures to rid herself of her waiting lady she said impatiently: "Jane, in the name of heaven don't keep so close to us.

column2: You won't move out of reach of my hand, and you know how often it inclines to box your ears."
column3: You won't move out of reach of my hand, and you know how often it inclines to box your ears."

column2: Jane did know, I am sorry for Mary's sake to say, how often the fair hand was given to such spasms; so with this emphasized hint she walked on ahead, half sulky at the indignity put upon her, and half amused at her whimsical mistress.
column3: Jane did know, I am sorry for Mary's sake to say, how often the fair hand was given to such spasms; so with this emphasized hint she walked on ahead, half sulky at the indignity put upon her, and half amused at her whimsical mistress.

column2: Mary lost no time, but began the attack at once.
column3: Mary lost no time, but began the attack at once.

column2: Now, sir, I want you to tell me the truth; why do you refuse my invitations and so persistently keep away from me?	Now, sir, I want you to tell me the truth; why do you refuse my invitations and so persistently keep away from me?

column2: I thought at first I would simply let you go your way, and then I thought I--would not. Don't deny it.
column3: I thought at first I would simply let you go your way, and then I thought I-would not. Don't deny it.

column2: I know you won't.
column3: I know you won't.

column2: With all your faults, you don't tell even little lies; not even to a woman--I believe.
column3: With all your faults, you don't tell even little lies; not even to a woman-I believe.

column2: Now there is a fine compliment--is it not?--when I intended to scold you!" She gave a fluttering little laugh, and, with hanging head, continued: "Tell me, is not the king's sister of quality sufficient to suit you?
column3: Now there is a fine compliment-is it not?--when I intended to scold you!" She gave a fluttering little laugh, and, with hanging head, continued: "Tell me, is not the king's sister of quality sufficient to suit you?

column2: Perhaps you must have the queen or the Blessed Virgin?
column3: Perhaps you must have the queen or the Blessed Virgin?

column2: Tell me now?" And she looked up at him, half in banter, half in doubt.
column3: Tell me now?" And she looked up at him, half in banter, half in doubt.

column2: My duties--, began Brandon.
column3: My duties-, began Brandon.

column2: Oh! bother your duties.	Oh! bother your duties.

column2: Tell me the truth."
column3: Tell me the truth."

column2: I will, if you let me, returned Brandon, who had no intention whatever of doing anything of the sort.

column2: My duties now occupy my time in the evening----
column3: My duties now occupy my time in the evening----

column2: That will not do, interrupted Mary, who knew enough of a guardsman's duty to be sure it was not onerous.
column3: That will not do, interrupted Mary, who knew enough of a guardsman's duty to be sure it was not onerous.

column2: You might as well come to it and tell the truth; that you do not like our society. And she gave him a vicious little glance without a shadow of a smile.
column3: You might as well come to it and tell the truth; that you do not like our society. And she gave him a vicious little glance without a shadow of a smile.

column2: In God's name, Lady Mary, that is not it, answered Brandon, who was on the rack.
column3: In God's name, Lady Mary, that is not it, answered Brandon, who was on the rack.

column2: Please do not think it.	Please do not think it.

column2: I cannot bear to have you say such a thing when it is so far from the real truth."
column3: I cannot bear to have you say such a thing when it is so far from the real truth."

column2: Then tell me the real truth.
column3: Then tell me the real truth.

column2: I cannot; I cannot.	I cannot; I cannot.

column2: I beg of you not to ask.
column3: I beg of you not to ask.

column2: Leave me! or let me leave you.
column3: Leave me! or let me leave you.

column2: I refuse to answer further."
column3: I refuse to answer further."

column2: The latter half of this sentence was uttered doggedly and sounded sullen and ill-humored, although, of course, it was not so intended.
column3: The latter half of this sentence was uttered doggedly and sounded sullen and ill humored, although, of course, it was not so intended.

column2: He had been so perilously near speaking words which would probably have lighted, to their destruction--to his, certainly--the smoldering flames within their breast that it frightened him, and the manner in which he spoke was but a tone giving utterance to the pain in his heart.
column3: He had been so perilously near speaking words which would probably have lighted, to their destruction-to his, certainly-the smoldering flames within their breast that it frightened him, and the manner in which he spoke was but a tone giving utterance to the pain in his heart.

column2: Mary took it as it sounded, and, in unfeigned surprise, exclaimed angrily: "Leave you?
column3: Mary took it as it sounded, and, in unfeigned surprise, exclaimed angrily: "Leave you?

column2: Do I hear aright?
column3: Do I hear aright?

column2: I never thought that I, the daughter and sister of a king, would live to be dismissed by a--by a--any one."
column3: I never thought that I, the daughter and sister of a king, would live to be dismissed by a-by a-any one."

column2: Your highness-- began Brandon; but she was gone before he could speak.
column3: Your highness- began Brandon; but she was gone before he could speak.

column2: He did not follow her to explain, knowing how dangerous such an explanation would be, but felt that it was best for them both that she should remain offended, painful as the thought was to him.
column3: He did not follow her to explain, knowing how dangerous such an explanation would be, but felt that it was best for them both that she should remain offended, painful as the thought was to him.

column2: Of course, Mary's womanly self-esteem, to say nothing of her royal pride, was wounded to the quick, and no wonder.
column3: Of course, Mary's womanly self esteem, to say nothing of her royal pride, was wounded to the quick, and no wonder.

column2: Poor Brandon sat down upon a stone, and, as he longingly watched her retiring form, wished in his heart he were dead.
column3: Poor Brandon sat down upon a stone, and, as he longingly watched her retiring form, wished in his heart he were dead.

column2: This was the first time he really knew how much he loved the girl, and he saw that, with him at least, it was a matter of bad to worse; and at that rate would soon be--worst.
column3: This was the first time he really knew how much he loved the girl, and he saw that, with him at least, it was a matter of bad to worse; and at that rate would soon be-worst.

column2: Now that he had unintentionally offended her, and had permitted her to go without an explanation, she was dearer to him than ever, and, as he sat there with his face in his hands, he knew that if matters went on as they were going, the time would soon come when he would throw caution to the dogs and would try the impossible--to win her for his own.
column3: Now that he had unintentionally offended her, and had permitted her to go without an explanation, she was dearer to him than ever, and, as he sat there with his face in his hands, he knew that if matters went on as they were going, the time would soon come when he would throw caution to the dogs and would try the impossible-to win her for his own.

column2: Caution and judgment still sat enthroned, and they told him now what he knew full well they would not tell him after a short time--that failure was certain to follow the attempt, and disaster sure to follow failure.
column3: Caution and judgment still sat enthroned, and they told him now what he knew full well they would not tell him after a short time-that failure was certain to follow the attempt, and disaster sure to follow failure.

column2: First, the king would, in all probability, cut off his head upon an intimation of Mary's possible fondness for him; and, second, if he should be so fortunate as to keep his head, Mary could not, and certainly would not, marry him, even if she loved him with all her heart.
column3: First, the king would, in all probability, cut off his head upon an intimation of Mary's possible fondness for him; and, second, if he should be so fortunate as to keep his head, Mary could not, and certainly would not, marry him, even if she loved him with all her heart.

column2: The distance between them was too great, and she knew too well what she owed to her position.
column3: The distance between them was too great, and she knew too well what she owed to her position.

column2: There was but one thing left--New Spain; and he determined while sitting there to sail with the next ship.
column3: There was but one thing left-New Spain; and he determined while sitting there to sail with the next ship.

column2: The real cause of Brandon's manner had never occurred to Mary. Although she knew her beauty and power, as she could not help but know it--not as a matter of vanity, but as a matter of fact--yet love had blinded her where Brandon was concerned, and that knowledge failed to give her light as to his motives, however brightly it might illumine the conduct of other men toward whom she was indifferent.
column3: The real cause of Brandon's manner had never occurred to Mary. column2: So Mary was angry this time; angry in earnest, and Jane felt the irritable palm more than once.
column3: So Mary was angry this time; angry in earnest, and Jane felt the irritable palm more than once.

column2: I, too, came in for my share of her ill temper, as most certainly would Brandon, had he allowed himself to come within reach of her tongue, which he was careful not to do.
column3: I, too, came in for my share of her ill temper, as most certainly would Brandon, had he allowed himself to come within reach of her tongue, which he was careful not to do.

column2: An angry porcupine would have been pleasant company compared with Mary during this time.
column3: An angry porcupine would have been pleasant company compared with Mary during this time.

column2: There was no living with her in peace.

column2: Even the king fought shy of her, and the queen was almost afraid to speak.
column3: Even the king fought shy of her, and the queen was almost afraid to speak.

column2: Probably so much general disturbance was never before or since collected within one small body as in that young Tartar-Venus, Mary.
column3: Probably so much general disturbance was never before or since collected within one small body as in that young Tartar Venus, Mary.

column2: She did not tell Jane the cause of her vexation, but only said she "verily hated Brandon," and that, of course, was the key to the whole situation.
column3: She did not tell Jane the cause of her vexation, but only said she "verily hated Brandon," and that, of course, was the key to the whole situation.

column3: After a fortnight, this ill humor began to soften in the glowing warmth of her heart, which was striving to reassert itself, and the desire to see Brandon began to get the better of her sense of injury.

column2: Brandon, tired of this everlasting watchfulness to keep himself out of temptation, and, dreading at any moment that lapse from strength which is apt to come to the strongest of us, had resolved to quit his place at court and go to New Spain at once.
column3: Brandon, tired of this everlasting watchfulness to keep himself out of temptation, and, dreading at any moment that lapse from strength which is apt to come to the strongest of us, had resolved to quit his place at court and go to New Spain at once.

column3: He had learned, upon inquiry, that a ship would sail from Bristol in about twenty days, and another six weeks later.

column2: So he chose the former and was making his arrangements to leave as soon as possible.
column3: So he chose the former and was making his arrangements to leave as soon as possible.

column2: He told me of his plans and spoke of his situation: "You know the reason for my going," he said, "even if I have never spoken of it.
column3: He told me of his plans and spoke of his situation: "You know the reason for my going," he said, "even if I have never spoken of it.

column2: I am not much of a Joseph, and am very little given to running away from a beautiful woman, but in this case I am fleeing from death itself. And to think what a heaven it would be.
column3: I am not much of a Joseph, and am very little given to running away from a beautiful woman, but in this case I am fleeing from death itself. And to think what a heaven it would be.

column2: I am unable to tell how I feel toward her.
column3: I am unable to tell how I feel toward her.

column2: It sometimes seems that I can not live another hour without seeing her; yet, thank God, I have reason enough left to know that every sight of her only adds to an already incurable malady. What will it be when she is the wife of the king of France?
column3: It sometimes seems that I can not live another hour without seeing her; yet, thank God, I have reason enough left to know that every sight of her only adds to an already incurable malady. What will it be when she is the wife of the king of France?

column2: Does it not look as if wild life in New Spain is my only chance?"

column2: I told Jane what Brandon was about to do, knowing full well she would tell Mary; which she did at once.

column2: Poor Mary!
column3: Poor Mary!

column2: She had not before fully known that she loved him.
column3: She had not before fully known that she loved him.
